The index coefficient is calculated as Coefficient (date) = Linked index (date) / Index base value based on the information defined within the Index calc. method tab.

title: Index calc. method
body: Fields to define the linked index:

title: Index calc. method
body: Calculation impact. Indicates if the defined linked index and index base value affect the Market value and accrued interest or Accrued interest. The first selection utilizes the linked index and index base value to calculate both the market value and accrued interests of an index linked bond according to the selected index convention, while the second selection applies the linked index and index base value only to the calculation of accrued interest according to the selected index convention, assuming that the market unit prices for the index linked bond are already index corrected.

title: Index calc. method
body: Linked index. The linked index from the securities defined in the system. The market prices from the selected linked index are used to calculate the coefficient used to value an index linked bond according to the selected index convention.

title: Index calc. method
body: Index base value . The value used to calculate the coefficient used to value an index linked bond according to the selected index convention.

title: Index calc. method
body: Fields to define the index convention:

title: Index calc. method
body: Index convention . A pre-defined index convention from the conventions used in different countries or regions. Selecting an appropriate convention from the alternatives pre-fills the following fields for calculation mode and lags according to the selected convention, and valuates your index linked bonds with the linked index and index base value according to the convention of the region. If you cannot find an appropriate pre-defined convention, choose Other, and define the calculation parameters yourself.

title: Index calc. method
body: Calculation mode . The calculation mode determines how the coefficient used to value an index linked bond is calculated based on the defined linked index and index base value:

title: Index calc. method
body: With Linear interpolation, the coefficient used in valuating index linked bonds is calculated with the interpolated value of the linked index for months defined in lag 1 and lag 2 prior to the settlement date of the bond. For example, Swedish idex linked bonds use an interpolated index value for 2 and 3 months prior to the bond's settlement date.

title: Index calc. method
body: With Direct calculation, the coefficient used in valuating index linked bonds is calculated with an index value taken for months back as defined in lag 1. For example, Finnish index linked bonds use 3-month lag with no interpolation.

title: Index calc. method
body: Lag 1 in months. A numeric value between 0 and 12, representing the lag 1 in months. Used both for direct calculation as months back, and in linear interpolation as the end point for the interpolation.

title: Index calc. method
body: Lag 2 in months . A numeric value between 0 and 12, representing the lag 2 in months. Used only in linear interpolation as the starting point for the interpolation.

title: Index calc. method
body: Pre-defined index conventions and the pre-filled values:

title: Redemption
body: Redemption tab allows you to define the redemption information for your security, relevant for example for partial expirations. This information is not directly used by the system, but allows you to store relevant information on redemptions.

title: Redemption
body: Fields to define the redemption information:

title: Redemption
body: Redemption . Redemption payment period: Annually, Semi-annually, Quarterly, Monthly, Weekly or Daily.

title: Redemption
body: First redemption date . The date of the first redemption after the security is issued. After the selected first redemption date, the following redemptions can be determined based on the frequency selected.

title: Redemption
body: You can also define individual redemptions manually. The manually-defined redemptions are listed at the bottom left corner of the window, ordered with the date defined, newest first. A new redemption is added from the Add redemption button, and the redemption information is defined in the fields at the right-hand side of the window:

title: Redemption
body: Fixing date*. The date of the redemption.

title: Redemption
body: Fixing* - define the value of the redemption as a percentage %.

title: Bond-related calculations
body: Bond-related calculations

title: Day count convention
body: Day count convention is used to convert dates to a numeric representation for financial maths, and is the base for accrued interest and coupon calculations for bond. For more information about day count conventions, see the Opengamma site.

title: Day count convention
body: Options for day count conventions are:

title: Day count convention
body: 30/360 ISDA

title: Day count convention
body: 30E/360 ISDA

title: Day count convention
body: 30U/360 EOM

title: Day count convention
body: Act/360

title: Day count convention
body: Act/364

title: Day count convention
body: Act/365 Actual

title: Day count convention
body: Act/365F

title: Day count convention
body: Act/365L

title: Day count convention
body: Act/366 – the same as Act/360, but uses 366 as the denominator instead of 360.

title: Day count convention
body: Act/366.375 – the same as Act/360, but uses 366.375 as the denominator instead of 360.

title: Day count convention
body: Act/Act AFB

title: Day count convention
body: Act/Act ICMA

title: Day count convention
body: Act/Act ISDA

title: Day count convention
body: Act/Act Year

title: Stub convention
body: Stub convention determines where to place a stub period in the bond's schedule, if one should occur. When determining a schedule (i.e. how often a coupon is paid), each date between the start date and end date based on the day count convention is allocated into a period. Most dates are allocated into a regular period, based on the selected frequency. Any dates left over are allocated to a stub, either at the start or end.

title: Business day convention
body: Business day convention determines how to adjust a date (such as coupon date of a bond) if it falls on a non-business day. The business day convention is a simple rule that specifies how to change the date from a holiday or weekend to a valid business day.

title: Roll convention
body: Roll convention allows you to override the standard approach of building a schedule for the bond, and determines how to roll the coupon payment date within the schedule. By default, roll convention is not set nor needed - bond's schedule is built automatically based on other bond information.

title: Roll convention
body: Most common roll conventions are "EOM" (end-of-month) and "IMM" (3rd Wednesday of each month). For example, roll convention “end-of-month” allows you to configure that the first date of a monthly schedule, such as June 30th, should roll to the last day of each month instead of the 30th of each month.

title: Roll convention
body: The concept is best illustrated with an example:

title: Roll convention
body: We have a bond with a frequency Every three months and the first fixing date is on a last day of a month with 30 days, such as June 30th.

title: Roll convention
body: With standard approach of generating the schedule, the coupon dates would fall on the 30th of each month (September 30th, December 30th, March 30th, etc.). For months with 31 days, the coupon date would not be the last day of the month.

title: Roll convention
body: If we want the coupon date to be the last day of each quarter (instead of the 30th), we can select the roll convention End of Month (EOM). With this selection, the system will recognize that June 30th is the last day of the month, and the coupon dates would fall on the last day of each month (September 30th, December 31st, March 31st, etc.).

title: Ex-coupon period
body: Ex-coupon period determines the number of days before the coupon payment date during which the bond is traded ex-coupon, or without coupon (if the bond is bought during the ex-coupon period, the next coupon is paid to the previous holder of the bond, not the buyer).

title: Ex-coupon period
body: From Investopedia: "The ex-coupon date can be defined as the date by which the trade must occur if the buyer is to receive the upcoming coupon."

title: Ex-coupon period
body: The ex-coupon date is determined using the ex-coupon period setting, so that the ex-coupon date is the date that is the specified amount of days before the settlement date. Effectively, whoever holds the bond when that day ends, still gets the coupon. If the trade settles after that date, up until the settlement date, the next coupon goes to the previous owner (the seller) of the bond, and the buyer must be compensated for the few days' worth of interest that accrues while they are holding the bond, as the coupon will be paid in full to the seller.

title: Ex-coupon period
body: As the ex-coupon date is the last date when the next coupon will still go to the buyer, the ex-coupon period values 0 and 1 mean effectively the same thing, since on the coupon date the coupon is paid to whomever is entitled to receive it.

title: Ex-coupon period
body: The concept is best illustrated with an example:

title: Ex-coupon period
body: Let's say we have a bond whose next coupon date is 7 January. The ex-coupon period for the bond is 3 days, which means the ex-coupon date is 4 January, using a "no holidays" holiday calendar. This means that, in order for the buyer to be eligible to receive the upcoming coupon, the trade must settle on 4 January at the latest.

title: Ex-coupon period
body: For clarity, the example above assumes all days are business days, which corresponds to using a "no holidays" holiday calendar. When calculating date offsets (ex-coupon period and settlement date offset), the effective holiday calendar is considered, skipping weekends and other non-business days.

title: Description
body: Description tab allows you to write an optional and more detailed description of the security.

title: Allocation
body: Allocation tab allows you to define the allocation of the security. The allocations related to an asset group defined for the security are listed on the left-hand side of the window: a security can have an allocation for each asset group defined in Asset classes and types Preferences. You can find the list of allocations available in Standard Solution in FA User guide: Asset classes and asset types.

title: Allocation
body: For example, you can define geographical and industry-based allocations separately.

title: Allocation
body: You can view and modify the allocation information by choosing the corresponding allocation group from the listing on the left. You can add a new allocation, and define the allocation information on the right-hand side of the window.

title: Allocation
body: When defining an allocation, first choose the asset group you want to use (e.g. are you defining geographical or industry-based allocation). Second, select the date from which the allocation is valid from for the security and add it to your allocation definition. The start date should usually be set before this security appears in your portfolios (i.e. when your portfolios start getting in transactions for this security) - if the allocation starts later than the first transactions for this security come in, this security is allocated as Other until the date it is valid from. If you want to update your allocation's content, add a new date to it - the new content will be valid from the new date onward, while the prior index content will be used until the new date.

title: Allocation
body: Below each date you can see the content of the allocation. You can add a new asset type under the selected date: you need to define the asset type and the share of this asset type from the whole allocation. For each new position under the selected date, choose the asset type from the drop-down menu. In the field next to it, define the share of the selected asset type of the whole allocation. If the allocation consists of a single asset type, define the share as 100 % - if the share of the selected asset type is less than 100, you have to create new positions and define their shares so that the sum of the shares of different asset types under one date equals 100.

title: Market data info
body: Market data info tab allows you to view and modify the market data information of a security.

title: Market data info
body: Market data entries are listed based on the date, newest first. The Close column shows you the close price of the day, or the market price that is used for the security for that date - this Close price is by default used when calculating the market value of positions in this security. The Close price is determined by the values of the other columns, Manual, Close 1, Close 2, Close 3, Close 4 and Close 5 together with the value of the Source filed on the Basic info tab as follows:

title: Market data info
body: If the value of the Source field is set to Default, the first non-empty value is selected for the Close price when going through the columns from left to right. In other words, the value of the Close column is determined by default by the Manual column, then by Close 1 and so forth. The market price inserted in the Manual column always overrides the prices in the other columns for one date.

title: Market data info
body: If the value of the Source field is set to one of the columns, only the values in that column are taken into account when determining Close price. For example, if the value of the Source field is set to Close 1, the value of the Close column will be determined only by the Close 1 column: if there is a market price entry in the Manual column for a certain date but no Close 1 entry, no market price is chosen to the Close field for that date.

title: Market data info
body: In addition, you can select a Source value for a portfolio, when the portfolio uses the market values of the securities within it based on the above logic and the Source defined for the portfolio.

title: Market data info
body: You can modify an individual market data entry by choosing it from the listing. You can add a market data entry for the security with the Add market data button: define the new market price entry in the available fields.

title: Market data info
body: Date*

title: Market data info
body: Choose the date of the market data entry.

title: Market data info
body: Manual

title: Market data info
body: Manually define the market price for the date.

title: Market data info
body: Close 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5

title: Market data info
body: Define the market price you received from your market data source into the corresponding close field. Recommendation is to use a Close field that corresponds with the Update code field you have defined in security's Basic info: the market data entry received from the price source defined in the Update code 1 field is entered in the Close 1 field and so forth. In order to be able to define the price, first enable the field(s) you are using with the checkbox above the field.

title: Market data info
body: Accrual

title: Market data info
body: Define the value of accrual included in the market price. Accrual is tracked along with a market price, and the value in the accrual field indicates how much accrued income in security currency was included in that day’s market price - the accrual defined on the security is used to calculate your position's accrual as Amount*Accrual.

title: Market data info
body: Accrual is recommended to be recorded along with a market price (i.e. a value in manual / one of the close fields), but you can track accrual also on its own. (Available from FA 3.7 onward) Your position's market value excludes your position's accrual, while your position's market unit price includes accrual, and market value (d) includes your position's accrual (available from FA 3.8 onward).

title: Market data info
body: Delta

title: Market data info
body: Define the value for delta. Delta defined on the security is used to calculate your position's exposure - if your security has delta, then the exposure is multiplied by delta. If delta is not found on the latest market data observation relative to the valuation date, delta is assumed to be 1. If security has price on the valuation date of 2020-01-30, but no delta is recorded on that date, delta is assumed to be 1. Even if delta is found on 2020-01-29, that delta is not used, since it was not found on the same date as the latest price. Thus, delta should always be recorded along with a market price, and value of delta is picked along with the market price used. (Available from FA 3.7 onward)

title: Market data info
body: When the market data information is filled in, save the market data entry with the OK button below the fields. Versions button allows you to view the versions of each market data entry.

title: Market data info

title: Market data info
body: Calculate missing discount factors on your future cashflow securities - this button is only available if you have a permission to revaluate securities and the security's base type is DISCOUNT. For more information, see the Automatic and manual valuation in the Valuation of forward cashflows section.

title: Market data info
body: For bonds with appropriate bond information in the Extra information tab, FA also supports calculating the bond price based on importing YTM instead of bond price to the system. For more information, see the File formats for importing securities and security prices section. Price can be imported with % (e.g. 3.45%), when the system calculates the price according to YTM automatically.

title: Key figures
body: Key figures tab allows you to store a time series of values of your choice - you can for example store different ratings (CO2 rating, credit rating, etc.) or other values to your securities. For more information, see the Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities section.

title: Key figures
body: In addition to the configurable key figures, for bond and fund securities, the key figures tab allows you to manually set certain security-specific key figures to be used instead of values calculated by FA. For more information, see the Security key figures section.

title: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs
body: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs tab allows you to define ex-ante and ex-post cost percentages under your security, allowing you to record and categorize all security-related costs. Define a date from which your cost categorization is valid from, and define the security's costs as percentages according to your desired categorization. This cost categorization can be used in ex-ante and ex-post cost analysis and reporting.

title: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs
body: Date*

title: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs
body: Define a date from which your cost percentages are valid from. You can update your security costs by adding a new date and defining new cost percentages - the new values will be considered starting from the date you define.

title: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs

title: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs
body: Define ex-ante cost percentages for your security. You can break down the security's ex-ante costs into One-off charges, On-going charges, Charges related to transactions, Charges related to ancillary services or Incidental charges, or you can use up to five additional Other cost categories to categorize your costs even more extensively.

title: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs

title: Ex-ante / Ex-post costs
body: Full ex-post disclosure of costs, calculated based on the defined cost categories, is available then on Analytics+ or on a specific Ex-post costs report.

title: Documents
body: Document tab allows you to manage documents related to your securities. For more information, see the Document management section.

title: Saving security
body: Saving a security saves the security into the system, and after you save the security, you can for example create transactions or trade orders on it. When editing the information of an existing security, usually saving is enough - the updated information is picked up by the system automatically.

title: Saving security
body: However, there are certain scenarios when you need to click Save & close (update) in order for the system to recalculate all affected portfolio reports for your changes to take effect.

title: Saving security
body: At the bottom of the Security window, you can:

title: Saving security
body: Save and close

title: Saving security
body: Saves the security / the changes made to the security information and closes the window.

title: Saving security
body: Save

title: Saving security
body: Saves the changes made to the security information, and takes you back to the Basic info tab.

title: Saving security
body: Save and close (update)

title: Saving security
body: Saves the security, closes the window and recalculates all affected portfolios' report data. This might affect multiple portfolios and the update might be triggered for a long period of time, depending on how many portfolios contain the security! Update is only necessary if you modify the below information, otherwise saving without an update is enough and avoids unnecessary report recalculations.

title: Saving security

Report data no longer depends on security codes, and thus changing the code no longer requires an update - your positions are up-to-date even when security codes are changed.)

body: Translate

title: Saving security
body: Allows you to add translations for the security name and description. This allows you to have different, translated names for your securities, that can for example be used in reporting in different languages.

title: Saving security
body: Saving a security is audited when saving the security might result in report recalculations - user audit tracks user clicks Save and close (update) button or saving and closing the Security window after modifying security's market data. Every time a user clicks Save and close (update) in the Security window, user audit contains a message ”User [username] clicked Save and close (update) in Security window for security [code]”, and every time a user updates security's market data through the Market data info tab and closes the window (either through first clicking Save and then closing the window or directly clicking roleSave&close), user audit contains a message ”User [username] closed the Security window for security [code]”. Also, every time a report recalculation is started, the system audit logs which portfolios' reports are recalculated and from which date onward. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Related links
body: Manage securities in FA User guide

title: Preferences - Securities
body: Security preferences allow you to set the options available in the fields when defining the basic information of a security in the Basic info tab on the Security window. This allows you to flexibly group and categorize your securities.

title: Asset classes and types
body: Asset classes and types can be defined in the Asset classes and Asset types window in the Preferences. The definition of the asset classes and types has three levels: you can define asset groups on the highest level, asset classes on the middle level, and on the lower level you can define asset types for the asset classes.

title: Asset classes and types
body: You can modify the order of the asset groups, classes and types by dragging the asset group, class or type to the preferred position in the listing. You can also move asset types from an asset class to another. When the order of the asset classes and types has bee changed, the new order has to be saved with the Update order button. The order saved for the asset classes and types is used for example to show the asset classes and types in reports.

title: Asset classes and types
body: A new asset group is added with the Add group button. An asset group consists of a code and a name: the code is used to identify the asset group in the system, and the name is used to view and choose the asset group in the user interface and reports. The asset group represents a set of asset classes and types: you can define different sets of asset classes and types under each group. For example, geographical allocations can be defined in a different asset group from industry-based allocations.

title: Asset classes and types
body: A new asset class is added with the Add asset class button under a defined asset group. An asset class consists of a code and a name: the code is used to identify the asset class in the system, and the name is used to view and choose the asset class in the user interface and reports. The asset classes represent the higher level classifications within an asset group.

title: Asset classes and types
body: A new asset type is added with the Add asset type button under a defined asset class. An asset type consists of a code a name and a status: the code is used to identify the asset class in the system, the name is used to view and choose the asset class in the user interface and reports and the status is used to determine whether the type is available for securities (choose between Active and Passive). The asset classes represent the lower level classifications.

title: Manage parameters
body: In the manage parameters tab you can manage and modify the parameters, such as the volatility and expected return, for the saved asset types. The parameters can only be defined for asset types, not the main level asset classes.

title: Manage parameters
body: You can modify the parameters with the Edit button at the bottom of the window. The parameter information of asset types is divided into columns:

title: Manage parameters
body: Name

title: Manage parameters
body: The asset type name.

title: Manage parameters
body: Volatility %

title: Manage parameters
body: The volatility percent of the asset type.

title: Manage parameters
body: Expected return %

title: Manage parameters
body: The expected return percent of the asset type.

title: Manage parameters
body: The modified parameters can be saved with the Save button. The Cancel button closes the edit mode without saving.

title: Export/import correlations
body: In the Export/import correlations tab you can modify the correlations between the asset types. Correlations are shown in the tab as a matrix, and the correlations can be modified with an Excel file. To modify the correlations, export the correlations to an Excel file with the Export button, make the necessary changes and import the modified correlation file back to the system with the Upload file button.

title: Export/import correlations
body: There are three buttons visible:

title: Export/import correlations
body: Export

title: Export/import correlations
body: Export - export the correlations as an Excel file to enable modification of the correlations

title: Export/import correlations
body: Upload file

title: Export/import correlations
body: - import the modified correlation file back to the system to modify correlations

title: Export/import correlations
body: Save

title: Export/import correlations
body: - save the changes made to the correlation matrix with the exported and imported file

title: Asset type - benchmark
body: The Asset type- benchmark tab can be accessed with the Benchmark button under each asset type. The tab allows you to create a Benchmark to the asset type, similar to creating a benchmark to a portfolio.

title: Base currency
body: Base currency preferences allows you to define the base currency of the system.

title: Base currency
body: You can select the system's base currency out of existing securities of the type CURRENCY - if your desired currency is not available, you can add it to the list by creating a new currency security. System's base currency should usually be set according to the currency you are getting most of your FX rates against, and is usually the currency you are using most often in valuating your investments within your portfolios. For example, if most of your portfolios are in EUR, and you are getting most of your FX rates against EUR (EUR/USD, EUR/SEK, EUR/GBP etc.), then your systems base currency should be EUR.

title: Base currency
body: System's base currency is used to calculate FX rates for a currency cross that has not been set up in the system - the system can calculate such an FX rate through the base currency, if relevant currency crosses have been define against the base currency. For example, if the system's base currency is EUR and the system would need an FX rate USD/SEK but it cannot find either USD/SEK or SEK/USD currency cross from the system, the system can calculate the USD/SEK FX rate through currency crosses defined against the base currency EUR, i.e. EUR/USD and EUR/SEK (or USD/EUR and SEK/EUR, respectively).

title: Block size
body: Block size preferences allows you to define the effect of the block size defined in the Security window.

title: Block size
body: Enable Block size affects multiplier / Block size affects multiplier 2 if you want the block size to affect multiplier or multiplier 2 in the Security window. If enabled, when you set a value in the Block size field, the multiplier(s) are automatically set accordingly. This setting helps you configure some types of securities, for example index futures, more easily: you can only set the block size, which will then automatically adjust the multipliers accordingly. By default, neither of the options is selected, and setting a block size has no effect on multipliers.

title: Class (1 - 5)
body: In the Class preferences you can define the classes available for securities. The classes are used to categorize securities, and the individual categorization systems are free of choice. The classification systems can be in any way useful to the user, and securities can be categorized with up to five different categorization system. For example, you can categorize your securities with the level of risk in Class 1 (e.g. low risk / medium risk / high risk) and with the credit rating in Class 2.

title: Class (1 - 5)
body: Classes can be defined in the Class window in the Preferences. A class consists of a code and a name: the code is used to identify the class in the system, and the name is used to view and choose the class in the user interface. Five classification systems are separate: for example, the values defined in Class 1 can only be chosen to the Class 1 field of the security.

title: Default holiday calendar
body: Default holiday calendar preferences allow you to set the default holiday calendar used when creating a new security. Holiday calendar on a security is used to distinguish business days from holidays, and used for example when setting a settlement date on a trade on the security.

title: Default holiday calendar
body: Set the default holiday calendar by selecting it from the dropdown. The dropdown lists all available holiday calendars in the system - whichever holiday calendar you select is used as the default holiday calendar for any new security you create. By default, the default holiday calendar is set to "Saturday/Sunday weekends (SatSun)".

title: Holiday calendar
body: Holiday calendar preferences provide you with tools to configure holiday calendars, allowing you to flexibly accommodate to different conventions in different markets. Holiday calendars distinguish between business days and holidays, and are used for example in accrued interest and coupon calculations for bonds and to determine settlement dates for transactions and trade orders.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Holiday calendar preferences allow you either to:

title: Holiday calendar
body: Customize system's built-in holiday calendars by adding individual holiday dates.

title: Holiday calendar
body: This allows you customize the system's built-in calendars when needed, for example in order to accommodate to individual non-regular holidays on certain markets such as king's funeral on a certain date.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Configure entirely new holiday calendars.

title: Holiday calendar
body: This allows you to build entirely new holiday calendars from scratch for a new market.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Existing holiday calendars are listed on left. There are three different kinds of calendars you can configure, identified with stars (* or **) in front of the holiday calendar code allowing you to easily distinguish what kind of a calendar you are working with:

title: Holiday calendar
body: **CODE - entirely new holiday calendars. These calendars you can freely modify and delete, since they have been configured from scratch. Once created, you can modify the calendar name, which days are weekend days, and which individual dates are considered as holidays.

title: Holiday calendar
body: *CODE - customized built-in holiday calendars. For these calendars, you can manage the custom holiday dates added to built-in calendar, but cannot modify other parameters of the calendar. If you delete this kind of a calendar, you in practice delete the custom dates you have added to the built-in holiday calendar, and fall back to the original system's built-in holiday calendar you customized in the first place.

title: Holiday calendar
body: CODE - system's built-in holiday calendars. These calendars you cannot modify or delete, but you can make them customized built-in holiday calendars by adding holiday dates to them.

title: Holiday calendar
body: After selecting a holiday calendar from the list, you can manage the calendar through the following fields and buttons:

title: Holiday calendar
body: Code

title: Holiday calendar
body: Unique holiday calendar code. Editable only for entirely new holiday calendars, system's built-in calendars have fixed codes.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Name

title: Holiday calendar
body: Name of the holiday calendar. Editable only for entirely new holiday calendars, system's built-in calendars have fixed names.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Weekend days

title: Holiday calendar
body: Allows you to tick which weekdays (options from Monday through Sunday) are considered as weekend days within your calendar. For example, if Saturdays and Sundays are weekend days within the market you are configuring the calendar from, ticking Sat and Sun will automatically mark all Saturdays and Sundays as holidays. This setting is only available for entirely new holiday calendars, system's built-in holiday calendars already consider weekend days as holidays as relevant for each market.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Add a holiday

title: Holiday calendar
body: Allows you to manually add a new holiday date to your holiday calendar. Define the holiday date in the available date field and add it with the Add button.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Import/Export

title: Holiday calendar
body: Allows you to mass-modify the holiday dates within your holiday calendar all at once as text. You can for example easily copy-paste a list of holiday dates from somewhere else to add them to your holiday calendar. Import/Export allows you to enter holiday dates, each date on its own row with format dd.MM.yyyy - the date format corresponds with the date format configured for your user interfaces language, allowing you to view and add dates with the same date format as you see dates on the screen.

title: Holiday calendar
body: Preview

title: Holiday calendar
body: Preview icon allows you to easily Preview the selected holiday calendar to check which days are marked as holidays (i.e. non-business days) within your calendar. Preview is available for all kinds of calendars, and allows you to see all dates that are considered as holidays. The calendar is by default opened for current date, but you can navigate back and forward to any date either with the date selector on the top left or with the arrows above the calendar.

title: Holiday calendar
body: For entirely new calendars, the preview combines the weekend days you ticked and the holidays you added, and marks all as "Holidays".

title: Holiday calendar
body: For customized built-in holiday calendars, the preview combines the holiday dates from the underlying system's built-in holiday calendars and the holidays you have added manually, and marks all as "Holidays".

title: Holiday calendar
body: For system's built-in holiday calendars, the preview shows the holiday dates from the system's built-in holiday calendars, and marks them as "Holidays".

title: Marketplace
body: In the Marketplace preferences you can define the marketplaces available for securities and transactions and exchanges available for contacts. The marketplace tells, where a security (or a transaction) is traded or in which exchanges a counter operates or a customer's custody lies. For example, the market places can include markets where securities are traded or trades are executed, such as OMX or NASDAQ.

title: Marketplace
body: Marketplaces can be defined in the Marketplace window in the Preferences. A marketplace consists of a code and a name: the code is used to identify the marketplace in the system (if using for example SWIFT messages, define the valid MIC code for the marketplace), and the name is used to view and choose the marketplace in the user interface.

title: Marketplace
body: In addition, you can define additional details to your marketplaces: these details include fields for Type, Country, MIC and Operating MIC. These details can for example be used when sending out your trades. This information is also available as selectable columns on the Securities view, allowing you to easily see the details of the marketplace you have linked to your securities.

title: Security types
body: Security type Preferences allow you to define the security types available for your securities. Security types are derived from a set of system-level "basic types", and define the characteristics of the securities of that type, how the securities of this type are managed in calculations, and what Transaction types are linked to this security type. For example, you can have multiple security types derived from the basic type FUND, such as "Mutual fund" and "ETF": both are derived from the same basic type FUND, but can otherwise have different characteristics.

title: Security types
body: Security type Preferences allow you to manage your security types. Existing security types are listed on the left - view the characteristics and modify the details of an existing security type through selecting it from the listing. Translate button allows you to save translations for the security type to be used in reports and the user interface, when a language other than the language of the security type is chosen.

title: Security types
body: Next to the security type listing, you can find two buttons, Up and Down. These buttons allow you to change the order of the security types in the listing: choose a security type you want to move, and move it up and down the listing with the buttons. Changing the order of the security types affects certain reports and the Overview: these functions order the securities shown based on the security type, and this order is defined by ordering the security types in the Security type preferences.

title: Security types
body: A new security type is added with the Add security type button. The security type information is defined in the fields on the right-hand side of the window. A red star indicates that a field is mandatory.

title: Security types
body: Code*

title: Security types
body: The individual security type code that separates it from other security types.

title: Security types
body: Name*

title: Security types
body: The name of the security type.

title: Security types
body: Basic type*

title: Security types
body: Choose the basic type of the security from the alternatives: STOCK, BOND, OPTION, FUTURE, CASH, FUND, DISCOUNT, CURRENCY, DEPOSIT, INDEX, CURRENCY_CROSS, and CONTRACT. Basic type determines what kind of fields are available in the Security window and Transaction window, controls how the security type is handled when calculating your portfolio's positions, and controls where the security is selectable within the system. For more details, see Characteristics of Basic types below.

title: Security types
body: Decimal count*

title: Security types
body: Define how many decimals are allowed for the amount in the cash transactions created for this security type. For security types with the base type CURRENCY, decimal count also determines how many decimals are used to show "cash" within the system. For example, if you handle cash (prices, costs, taxes, trade amounts, etc.) with three decimals, set the CURRENCY security type's decimal count to 3.

title: Security types
body: You can also define the number of decimals on the security level in the Security window, Block size field. For details, see Security window.

title: Security types
body: Valuation method

title: Security types
body: Define how the positions of this type are valuated within your portfolios through the alternatives: Use portfolio's valuation method (default), Always use FIFO or Always use average price. By default, all positions are valuated according to the valuation method you have set on your portfolio in your portfolio basic info - however, you can override the portfolio's valuation method on the security type level if needed. For example, your custody might valuate certain positions differently than you have chosen to valuate your portfolios - even though you value your portfolios with "average price", you can override the valuation for "futures" to always be "FIFO", or even though you value your portfolios with "FIFO", you can override the valuation for "private equity" to always be "average price".

title: Security types
body: TWR calculation

title: Security types
body: Define which TWR calculation method is used for the security type. See TWR calculation logic for more details on the methods and related calculations. (Available from FA 3.8 onward)

title: Security types
body: Default logic - If security is defined to be “Future contract” in the security type configuration, the method is Exposure based, otherwise it is Market value based. Accounts/cash uses Carry costs/profits to portfolio level logic. This is the default selection for security types.

title: Security types
body: Based on market value - Use Market value as the base value in the TWR calculation.

title: Security types
body: Based on exposure - Use Absolute exposure as the base value in the TWR calculation.

title: Security types
body: Carry costs/profits to portfolio level - Uses market value based TWR, but carries costs/profits to portfolio level. This means costs/profits does not affect the position level TWR but are taken into account on portfolio level TWR. Normally used e.g. on cash positions to aggregate up portfolio level costs to portfolio level, and not show their effect on account level e.g. management fees.

title: Security types
body: Don't calculate TWR on position level - Does not calculate / show TWR on positions of securities of this security type.

title: Security types
body: Group by type

title: Security types
body: Choose from the alternatives: No, Yes - same or Yes - opposite. The selection defines, whether the securities are grouped by type in the reports, in other words, are positions shown separately (Yes) or calculated together (No).

title: Security types
body: Include in total

title: Security types
body: Choose from the alternatives: Yes, No, Yes (change) or Yes (margin). The selection defines, whether the securities' market values are calculated in the portfolio total as the are (Yes) or not at all (No). Alternatively, the difference between the market value and purchase value can be added to the portfolio total (Yes (change)) or the margin account's value can be used to track the effect on the total value (Yes (margin)).

title: Security types
body: Future contract

title: Security types
body: Choose from the alternatives: No, Yes - charge cost later or Yes - charge cost immediately. The selection defines, whether the security is a forward type security and the transaction realizes in the future (Yes options) and whether the costs of such a transaction are charged immediately (Yes - charge cost immediately) or when the transaction realizes (Yes - charge cost later).

title: Security types
body: Links to transaction types

title: Security types
body: Define the transaction types to be used with this security type, defined in the Transaction types preferences. The transaction types are listed with the transaction type codes defined in the transaction type preferences. The available transaction types are listed on the left-hand side of this section, and the transaction types linked to the security type are listed on the right-hand side section. A transaction type is linked to the security type by choosing the desired transaction type from the left-hand side listing and pressing the >> button, when the transaction type is moved to the linked transaction types listing on the right-hand side. Similarly, a transaction type can be removed from the linked transaction types by choosing it from the right-hand side listing and pressing the << button. Only the transaction types linked to a security can be chosen as the transaction type of the transaction created to the security type.

title: Security types
body: Subtype

title: Security types
body: The sub types defined for the security type. The subtypes are more detailed description of the basic security types: for example, a security type bond could have subtypes fixed rate bond, floating rate note, convertible bond and government bond. The sub types are listed in this section: subtypes can be modified with the Modify button below the subtype listing.

title: Security types
body: The security type is saved with the Save button below the fields.

title: Security types
body: Changes in security types are audited - user audit tracks changes users make in Security type Preferences. Every time a user makes a change in security types, user audit contains a message ”User [username] created/modified/deleted security type [code]”. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Characteristics of Basic types
body: Security's Basic type determines what kind of fields are available in the Security window and Transaction window for creating this type of a security or when creating transactions for this type of a security, controls how the security type is handled when calculating your portfolio's positions, and controls where the security is selectable within the system. The table below summarizes the built-in characteristics of the available Basic types.

title: Settlement place
body: In the Settlement place preferences you can define the settlement places available for securities and transactions. The settlement place tells, where a transaction (or a security) is settled. For example, the settlement places can include settlements such as Euroclear.

title: Settlement place
body: Settlement places can be defined in the Settlement place window in the Preferences. A settlement place consists of a code and a name: the code is used to identify the settlement place in the system (if using for example SWIFT messages, define the valid BIC code for the settlement place), and the name is used to view and choose the settlement place in the user interface.

title: Queries view
body: Queries view allows you to make customized searches against the FA database in SQL. Queries is an efficient way of searching and aggregating information that is not directly supported by the other search views. Queries can be used for example for mass searches and aggregating information.

title: Queries view
body: You can use queries either for ad-hoc searches, or you can save your queries for later use. When you save your query for later use, you can give it a descriptive name and decide who to share it with.

title: Queries view
body: You can:

title: Queries view
body: Make ad-hoc searches. Click Show query to enter the query, and then click Search. If a query takes too long or if you need to edit the parameters, click Stop.

title: Queries view
body: Save your queries for later use. When you save your query for later use, you can give it a descriptive name and decide who to share it with.

title: Queries view
body: Export the results of any query as PDF or XLS.

title: Queries view
body: Use your saved queries as sections within your Dashboard - If your query returns at least one numeric value, instead of showing the data as a table, you can draw the results of your query as a chart on the Dashboard.

title: Queries view
body: Save your saved queries as a report template - If your query supports the $P(portfolioId) parameter, you can save your query as a report template and use it as any other report. The queries saved as report templates are identified with the file icon within the saved query tab.

title: Queries view
body: Show data to your logged-in users in FA Front.

title: Queries view
body: Stop query execution if you want to cancel your search.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard lets you set up a fund or edit settings for an existing fund in FA Fund Management app. When you set up a fund in the FA Fund management app, FA creates a fund portfolio with the specified properties in FA Back to store the fund information and manage fund investments.

title: Fund wizard
body: To set up a new fund, click the Add fund button at the top-right of the NAV status view. To view and edit the settings of an existing fund, click the Edit fund button in the Fund details pane.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard fields are described below.

title: Basic info tab
body: The Basic info tab contains the basic information about the fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund company*

title: Basic info tab
body: A company the fund is administered by. Choose the company from the list of contacts available in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Language*

title: Basic info tab
body: The language to be used in portfolio reports. If the language is filled in the fund company's contact in FA Back, it is automatically copied to the Fund wizard when you set up a fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical*

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical form of the fund company. Copied from the company's contact in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund name.

title: Basic info tab
body: ID*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique fund ID used to identify the fund and search for funds. Best practice is not to include special characters in the ID – only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info tab
body: Currency*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund currency. Once you create a fund, the currency can't be changed.

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method*

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method for the fund portfolio:

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with separate items – Valuates portfolio with average price, but keeps track of original purchase dates.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO (combined) – Valuates the portfolio based directly on transactions in the subportfolios.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Portfolio type. Choose the type that corresponds to the fund portfolio.

title: Cash accounts
body: Cash accounts for the fund.

title: Cash accounts
body: Name*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account name.

title: Cash accounts
body: Currency*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account currency.

title: Cash accounts
body: Account number*

title: Cash accounts
body: The account number, for example the bank account number.

title: Cash accounts
body: Set as default account

title: Cash accounts
body: Set account as the default account of the portfolio. All transactions are by default created against this account.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: The NAV schedules tab contains schedule settings for calculating NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV for the fund. Schedules let you track your fund's status. For example, you can see if NAV or fees have to be calculated today. You need to fill the dates only once. After that, dates are updated every time you accept the calculation.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: NAV schedules tab features settings for different workflows. You can set a schedule to calculate:

title: NAV schedules tab
body: NAV and fees as a part of regular NAV calculation workflow.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Fees, in addition to the regular NAV calculation schedule, between the regular NAV calculation dates (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add separate fee calculation schedule).

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Unofficial NAV for reporting purposes between the scheduled regular NAV calculations (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add unofficial NAV calculation schedule).

title: NAV schedules tab
body: To learn more about calculation workflows, see Workflows and NAV statuses.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Frequency

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Calculation frequency.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Holiday calendar

title: NAV schedules tab
body: The holiday calendar to take into account in the calculation schedule. If you don't find a suitable holiday calendar from the list, you can create a calendar in FA Back (for details, see Holiday calendar in the FA Back reference).

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Roll convention

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Calculation schedule based on the day of the month or day of the week. One of the most common roll conventions is "EOM" (end-of-month).

title: NAV schedules tab
body: You set the calculation frequency to "Every three months" and the first calculation date is on June 30th. The calculation dates will fall on the 30th of each month (September 30th, December 30th, March 30th, and so on). For months with 31 days, the calculation date won't be the last day of the month. If you choose the "End of Month (EOM)" roll convention, the system will recognize that June 30th is the last day of the month, and the calculation dates will fall on the last day of each month (September 30th, December 31st, March 31st, and so on).

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Business day convention

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Business day convention determines how to adjust a date if it falls on a non-business day.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: First NAV date

title: NAV schedules tab
body: The date for which NAV is calculated for the first time.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Previous NAV date

title: NAV schedules tab
body: The date for which the latest NAV was calculated. For the newly created fund, previous NAV date must be the same as the first NAV date.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Calculation delay in days

title: NAV schedules tab
body: The number of days between the NAV date and the calculation date. Enter "0" to calculate NAV ont he same date, or choose the number of days to calculate NAV with a delay.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Calculate next days

title: NAV schedules tab
body: The button sets the next NAV date and calculation dates according to the information entered above.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Next NAV date

title: NAV schedules tab
body: The next NAV date based on the frequency, holiday calendar conventions and the first NAV date chosen above.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date based on the based on the previous NAV date and calculation delay.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Next calculation date

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Next calculation date based on the next NAV date and calculation delay

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab lets you set or edit the fees applied to the whole fund. Click the Add fee button to add more than one fee formula.

title: Fee structure tab
body: To add fees per share class, use the Share class wizard.

title: Fee structure tab
body: Fee formula

title: Fee structure tab
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fee structure tab
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fee structure tab
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fee structure tab
body: Percentage

title: Fee structure tab
body: Fee percentage.

title: Fee structure tab

With two-factor authentication, users are required to enter a verification code in addition to their basic credentials (user ID and password) when logging in to FA.

title: Two-factor authentication block

title: Two-factor authentication block

title: Two-factor authentication block

title: Two-factor authentication block

title: Brute force detection block
body: Brute force detection identifies an attempt to guess a user’s password. With brute force detection, the user's account is temporarily disabled after a certain number and frequency of login failures. The user account is disabled for one minute if:

title: Brute force detection block
body: The user enters incorrect credentials twice within a second. This means that someone tries to guess the password programmatically.

title: Brute force detection block
body: The user fails to enter correct credentials 5 times. After the account is disabled, every unsuccessful attempt increases the lock by one minute, up to one hour.

title: Brute force detection block
body: The Brute force detection block includes the following information:

title: Brute force detection block
body: Status

title: Brute force detection block
body: User account status: Blocked (deactivated by brute force detection), or Unblocked (active). A user blocked by brute force detection has to wait for up to 1 hour (depending on the number of unsuccessful login attempts) for the account to be unblocked.

title: Brute force detection block
body: Total login attempts

title: Brute force detection block
body: The number of failed login attempts.

title: Brute force detection block
body: Last attempt

title: Brute force detection block
body: The date and time of the last login attempt.

title: Brute force detection block
body: IP address

title: Brute force detection block
body: The IP address from which the last login attempt was made.

title: Brute force detection block
body: To activate a blocked user account, choose Unblock and activate. Once unblocked, your user can log in again without waiting for the system to unblock the user after a certain period of time.

title: Sessions block
body: The Sessions block shows a list of currently active sessions for the user. For example, the same user might have logged in with different browsers, having multiple sessions open at the same time. The list shows:

title: Sessions block

title: Sessions block

title: Sessions block

title: Sessions block
body: The date and time the user accessed an app within the session. If the user accesses only one app, this shows the time they logged in, or if your user accesses multiple apps, this shows the time the user last opened a new app.

title: Sessions block

title: Sessions block

title: Sessions block

title: Stub convention
body: Convention Description

title: Stub convention
body: None Explicitly states that there are no stubs. This option is used to indicate that the schedule evenly divides by the frequency, leaving no stubs. For example, 6 months can be exactly divided by a 3 month frequency.

title: Stub convention
body: Short initial Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the start. For example, 8 months with a 3 month frequency would result in a 2 month initial short stub followed by two periods of 3 months.

title: Stub convention
body: Long initial Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the start and combined with the next period, making a total period longer than the standard frequency. For example, 8 months with a 3 month periodic frequency would result in a 5 month initial long stub followed by one period of 3 months.

title: Stub convention
body: Smart initial Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the start. If this results in a stub of less than 7 days, the stub will be combined with the next period. If this results in a stub of 7 days or more, the stub will be retained. This is the equivalent of Long initial up to 7 days and Short initial beyond that. This convention appears to match that used by Bloomberg.

title: Stub convention
body: Short final Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the end. For example, 8 months with a 3 month frequency would result in two periods of 3 months followed by a 2 month final short stub.

title: Stub convention
body: Long final Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the end and combined with the previous period, making a total period longer than the standard frequency. For example, 8 months with a 3 month frequency would result in one period of 3 months followed by a 5 month final long stub.

title: Stub convention
body: Smart final Any remaining period, shorter than the frequency, will be allocated at the end. If this results in a stub of less than 7 days, the stub will be combined with the next period. If this results in a stub of 7 days or more, the stub will be retained. This is the equivalent of Long final up to 7 days and Short final beyond that. This convention appears to match that used by Bloomberg.

title: Stub convention
body: Both Both ends of the schedule have a stub. Days before the first period start date form the initial stub. Days after the last period end date form the final stub.

title: Business day convention
body: Convention Description

title: Business day convention
body: Following (default) Move to the next valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Modified following (without crossing month end) Move to the next valid business day, unless that is in the next month in which case move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Modified following (without crossing mid-month or month end) Move to the next valid business day, unless that is after the 15th of the month OR in the next month in which case move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Preceding Move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Modified preceding (without crossing month start) Move to the previous valid business day, unless that is in the previous month in which case move to the next valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: Nearest For Sunday and Monday, move to the next valid business day, for all other days, move to the previous valid business day.

title: Business day convention
body: No adjustment Make no adjustment.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: # Code Required Name Description

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 1 tr.parentPortfolio Yes Portfolio ID String (unique ID of the transaction's portfolio)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 2 tr.extId Transaction External ID External ID / number of you transaction. If left empty, an external ID is generated for the transaction by the system. In addition, system defines an internal ID as well. External ID is used in combination with #1 Portfolio ID to update existing transactions - if your external ID already exists, the existing transaction is updated.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 3 tr.type Yes Type Type code (configured in the system). E.g. buy, sell etc.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 4 tr.status Yes Status Define as a code: OK = Accepted DEL = Deleted NF = Not finished

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 5 tr.transactionDate Yes Transaction date yyyy-MM-dd

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 6 tr.settlementDate No Settlement date yyyy-MM-dd In addition, you can use numbers between 1 and 99 to set the settlement date (the settlement date is set the inserted number of business days after the transaction date). The transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 7 tr.maturityDate No Maturity date Not used. Only available for transactions on securities with base type DEPOSIT (not regular deposit transactions). Use format yyyy-MM-dd.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 8 tr.security No Security Security code of the transaction's security. Leave empty, if a cash transaction. In addition to security code, importing transactions is supported with ISIN code, trade code or update codes 1 through 3. When importing transactions by using ISIN code to identify the security, the system checks that the transaction’s currency (column #11 Currency) matches the found security’s currency, if there are multiple securities with the same ISIN code in the system.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 9 tr.securityType No Security type Security type code of the transaction's security's type (as configured in the system). Used to determine features of a transaction.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 10 tr.account No Account Account number, if transaction is directed to an account. You can use the an account linked to the portfolio or shared to the portfolio. Define AUTO to record the transactions to the account with the same currency as the transaction, if such an account is found, or to the default account of the portfolio, if suitable currency account is not found. Define DEFAULT to always direct the transaction to the portfolio's default account. The system ignores white spaces in account numbers, and is thus able to recognize account numbers (such as IBAN numbers) defined with or without white spaces.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 11 tr.currency No Currency Transaction's currency (define with the currency code). If you don't define a currency for your transaction, the system will automatically determine it based on your transaction's data (available from FA 3.9 onward). Transaction's currency is either 1) Transaction's security's currency (if transaction is linked to a security) 2) Transaction's account's currency (for transactions not linked to a security but linked to account, i.e. CASH transactions) 3) Transaction's portfolio's currency (for transactions not linked to a security nor account, i.e. CASH transactions with "No account") After 3.9, best practice is to leave the currency empty, and the system will determine it for you. Before FA 3.9, transaction's currency was a mandatory field: define the currency with the currency security's code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 12 tr.amount Yes Amount Number of units. Amount field only accepts the amount of decimals defined for the security type or as the block size of the security: if your file has more decimals in the amount, the amount is rounded to contain only accepted amount of decimals. If number of units is not available, you can leave it empty, when the system calculates the amount with "unitPrice" (#13) and "tradeAmount" (#14).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 13 tr.unitPrice Yes Unit price Unit price is security currency (trade currency). Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry. For bonds, unit price can be set with % (e.g. 3.45%), when the system calculates the price according to YTM automatically. If unit price is not available or it is inaccurate, you can leave it empty, when the system calculates the unit price with "amount" (#12) and "tradeAmount" (#14).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 14 tr.tradeAmount Yes Trade amount Value of the transaction in security currency (trade currency), i.e. money value of the transaction including costs, taxes, accrued interest etc. If trade amount is not available, you can leave it empty, when the system calculates the trade amount with "amount" (#12) and "unitPrice" (#13).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 15 tr.fxRate No FX rate Exchange rate for the transaction. When importing an FX rate, the system automatically determines whether the exchange rate is account exchange rate (column #41) and/or report exchange rate (column #42), and fills them in appropriately. Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 16 tr.tax No Tax Tax in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 17 tr.cost No Cost Fee in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 18 tr.cost2 No Cost 2 Credit fee in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 19 tr.origTransactionDate No Booked transaction date yyyy-MM-dd

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 20 tr.origUnitPrice No Booked unit price Booked unit price in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 21 tr.origTradeAmount No Booked trade amount Booked trade amount. Define AUTO to automatically calculate the booked trade amount by multiplying the amount with transaction day's market data entry.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 22 tr.origFxRate No Booked FX rate Booked exchange rate between trade currency and portfolio's report currency. Define AUTO to automatically use the original transaction day's market data entry.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 23 tr.accruedInterest No Accrued interest Accrued interest in trade currency. For bonds, the accrued interest can be set with "?", when the system calculates the accrued interest automatically. Define AUTO to automatically calculate the accrued interest.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 24 tr.reference No Reference Reference of the transaction, usually transaction's reference number. Reference is used in combination with #1 Portfolio ID to update existing transactions if you haven't defined #2 External ID in your import file - if your reference can be found from an existing transaction, the existing transaction is updated.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 25 tr.counter No Counter Counter (use contact ID)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 26 tr.counterPortfolio No Counter portfolio Counter portfolio (use portfolio code)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: (27) (Ext info) Not used. Use tr.description in column #31 instead.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 28 tr.intInfo No Internal info Internal transaction description

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 29 tr.basis No Basis Not used.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 30 tr.priority No Priority Intraday priority of a transaction. -1,1,2,3... The transaction with the lowest priority has the highest number defined in the priority field (0 is lower than 1 and -1 is lower than 0). The default priority is 0.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 31 tr.description No Description Description/comment on the transaction

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 32 tr.security2 No Security 2 Security code of the removed security (e.g. in the exchange, the one that is replaced)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 33 tr.ratio No Ratio Define the ratio with syntax x:x (e.g. 1:2 or 2:3.25). Ratio is used for example for splits and exchanges. For splits, define the ratio between the number of securities before and after the split (with ratio 1:2, one security before the split would become two securities after the split). For exchanges, define the ratio as how many new securities are received with one removed security (with ratio 1:2, one removed security would become two new securities after the exchange).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 34 tr.taxType No Tax type Tax type of the transaction defined with the tax type code

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 35 tr.marketPlace No Market place Use the exchange code / market place code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 36 tr.tradeTime No Trade time hh:mm:ss You can also define the trade time with time zone information with the syntax of hh:mm:ssContinent/City (e.g. 11:12:13Europe/Helsinki, use valid java time zones) - when the transaction is imported, the trade time is converted into the server's time zone.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 37 tr.tax2 No Tax 2 Tax in trade currency

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 38 tr.taxType2 No Tax 2 type Tax type of the transaction defined with the tax type code

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 39 tr.tags No Tags Comma-separated list of tags. Tags import allows you to add new tags: Standalone tags are added with a <tag name>. For example: Fund,Urgent.Single-select group tags should be added as <group name>-<tag name>. For example: office-Helsinki. If a transaction already has a tag with the same group name, the tag is replaced.Multi-select group tags should be added as a comma-separated list of values <group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: Campaign:EarlyBird,Campaign:Friends. If a transaction already has tags with the same group name, the new tag is added to the existing ones. You can use three minuses (---) syntax to remove a tag value: Standalone tags: ---<tag name>. For example: ---Fund,---Urgent.Single-select group tags: ---<group name>-<tag name>. For example: —office-Helsinki.Multi-select group tags: ---<group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: ---Campaign:EarlyBird,---Campaign:Friends. For details, see Removing transaction and trade order values with three minuses (---).

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 40 tr.settlementPlace No Settlement place Use the settlement code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 41 tr.accountFxRate No Account FX rate Exchange rate between trade currency and portfolio's account currency. Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry. If you are not sure whether you need account or report FX rate, use FX rate (column #15) instead, which automatically determines which one to use.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 42 tr.reportFxRate No Report FX rate Exchange rate between trade currency and portfolio's report currency. Define AUTO to automatically use the transaction day's market data entry. If you are not sure whether you need account or report FX rate, use FX rate (column #15) instead, which automatically determines which one to use.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 43 tr.coefficient No Coefficient Coefficient calculated from the linked security's price and index base value. Affects trade amount same as unit price. Define AUTO to automatically calculate coefficient on the transaction date from the linked security and index base value.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 44 tr.compCost1 No Break-down of cost 1 Define the break-down of costs as a list of transaction cost data with the syntax <type>=<value>. Types are from defined transaction cost type. E.g. BROK=15,ADV=22. If you also defined a Cost (column #17), your Break-down of cost 1 has to sum up to the total cost you defined! If you leave Cost empty, the system calculates it automatically as the sum of your break-down of costs.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 45 tr.compCost2 No Break-down of cost 2 Define the break-down of costs as a list of transaction cost data with the syntax <type>=<value>. Types are from defined transaction cost type. E.g. BROK=15,ADV=22. If you also defined a Cost 2 (column #18), your Break-down of cost 2 has to sum up to the total cost you defined! If you leave Cost empty, the system calculates it automatically as the sum of your break-down of costs.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 46 tr.costType1 No Transaction cost type 1 Type of selected transaction cost type. Value is from defined transaction cost type's type code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 47 tr.costType2 No Transaction cost type 2 Type of selected transaction cost type. Value is from defined transaction cost type's type code.

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 48 tr.hidden No Hidden Whether the transaction should be marked as hidden. Define as a number: 1 = Hidden 0 = Not hidden (default)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 49 tr.paymentDate No Payment date yyyy-MM-dd

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: 50 tr.accrual No Accrual Transaction's accrual, or the the paid/received accrued income which is recorded as part of the price (unit price x amount). Accrual has no effect of the trade amount (Available from FA 3.7 onward)

title: FA Format for importing transactions
body: (51) (Execution method) Not used for transactions, available only for trade orders. Value 0 is always used for transactions, since transactions don't have an execution method

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Convention Description

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Following Move to the next valid business day.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Modified following (without crossing mid-month or month end) Move to the next valid business day, unless that is after the 15th of the month OR in the next month in which case move to the previous valid business day.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Modified following (without crossing month end) Move to the next valid business day, unless that is in the next month in which case move to the previous valid business day.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Modified preceding (without crossing month start) Move to the previous valid business day, unless that is in the previous month in which case move to the next valid business day.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Nearest For Sunday and Monday, move to the next valid business day, for all other days, move to the previous valid business day.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: No adjustment Make no adjustment.

title: NAV schedules tab
body: Preceeding Move to the previous valid business day.
